content: Personally, I'm less concerned about the name than I am about the fact the site hasn't been rebuilt yet. The best response, IMO, would have been to rebuild BOTH towers, even taller, in the shortest time possible.
reply: Personally, I'm less concerned about the name than I am about the fact the site hasn't been rebuilt yet. The best response, IMO, would have been to rebuild BOTH towers, even taller, in the shortest time possible.
title: A new name for the building at Ground Zero

content: And ... the developer is looking for a government handout ... quote: New York, Mar 22 (PTI) The private developer responsible for rebuilding the World Trade Center site has asked the United States government for providing "crucial financial assistance," a media report says. Citing people familiar with the matter, the Wall Street Journal said: "The rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, already hobbled by years of delays and infighting, is facing fresh problems as private developer Larry Silverstein asks the government for crucial financial assistance." The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the government entity that owns the site, is eager to prevent the project from stalling, and is considering helping to finance at least one of Silverstein's planned three office towers, WSJ added quoting sources. Silverstein is requesting financing help on at least two of the three towers. The project, meant to be a symbol of the recovery after the September 11 terrorist attacks, has been through years of costly delays and acrimony. The plan for the 16-acre site includes five skyscrapers, a memorial, a transit hub, a shopping mall and a performing-arts center. Much of that was recently expected to open between 2011 and 2013. PTI "http://www.ptinews.com/pti%5Cptisite.nsf/0/6630599EF9FCA69A65257581003F74B7?OpenDocument" Not just NO ... but HELL NO.
quote: New York, Mar 22 (PTI) The private developer responsible for rebuilding the World Trade Center site has asked the United States government for providing "crucial financial assistance," a media report says. Citing people familiar with the matter, the Wall Street Journal said: "The rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, already hobbled by years of delays and infighting, is facing fresh problems as private developer Larry Silverstein asks the government for crucial financial assistance." The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the government entity that owns the site, is eager to prevent the project from stalling, and is considering helping to finance at least one of Silverstein's planned three office towers, WSJ added quoting sources. Silverstein is requesting financing help on at least two of the three towers. The project, meant to be a symbol of the recovery after the September 11 terrorist attacks, has been through years of costly delays and acrimony. The plan for the 16-acre site includes five skyscrapers, a memorial, a transit hub, a shopping mall and a performing-arts center. Much of that was recently expected to open between 2011 and 2013. PTI "http://www.ptinews.com/pti%5Cptisite.nsf/0/6630599EF9FCA69A65257581003F74B7?OpenDocument"
reply: And ... the developer is looking for a government handout ...  Not just NO ... but HELL NO.

content: Just to give a comparison. The Empire state building was built in a little over a year (1 year 3 months). You would think with all of this technology, it would be built in 6 months. Can't do that though. The job has to go on as long as possible. So people don't notice, they'll throw in delays and excuses as well.
reply: Just to give a comparison. The Empire state building was built in a little over a year (1 year 3 months). You would think with all of this technology, it would be built in 6 months. Can't do that though. The job has to go on as long as possible. So people don't notice, they'll throw in delays and excuses as well.

content: quote: Originally posted by Raunchy: quote: Originally posted by Knele: Freedom Tower is right up there with Freedom Fries...... What an idiotic comparison. The word Freedom Tower was a knee jerk reaction... yes it was needed... but it still was a kneejerk reaction... just like the word Freedom Fries. That said... I would love for a piece of the old tower to be made into a statue memoralizing that day. I know they kept some scrape for that purpose. I think a section, 2-3 stories high in the lobby would be fitting.

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: Originally posted by john2x: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Instead of a monument of sorts, it is becoming a monumental embarassment. At the rate it is going, by the time construction is completed there won't be anyone left alive that lived through that fateful day. Takes time to cart off all the contaminated soil and replace it which has been going on for years now at night in prep for the construction. LOL ... I've heard a lot of reasons/excuses for the delays ... but that's the first time I've heard that one. From a civil engineering standpoint it takes a year almost to get the foundations in... also, the old foundation would have to be demo'd or rendered inert. Both of which takes a long time. Finally... it appears that funding has become an issue. do you think that Obama or Congress should allocate funding for the project in light of everything else? Or would that be just one more barb that people can stick him with?

title: A new name for the building at Ground Zero

content: quote: From a civil engineering standpoint it takes a year almost to get the foundations in... also, the old foundation would have to be demo'd or rendered inert. Both of which takes a long time. Also incorporating rail and light rail(?) into the design and linking it in physically is not that easy Finally... it appears that funding has become an issue. do you think that Obama or Congress should allocate funding for the project in light of everything else? Those are all reasons I've heard before ... as well as the bickering among survivors/family members/first responders and the planners on the whole site design, piece parts of the site design, and the memorial design ... and the fact that the entire "Freedom Tower" building design was changed after the cornerstone was laid. I made my position on federal funding pretty clear earlier in the thread ... with no partisanship involved.

I made my position on federal funding pretty clear earlier in the thread ... with no partisanship involved.

content: Just to give a comparison. The Empire state building was built in a little over a year (1 year 3 months). You would think with all of this technology, it would be built in 6 months. Can't do that though. The job has to go on as long as possible. So people don't notice, they'll throw in delays and excuses as well.
reply: Just to give a comparison. The Empire state building was built in a little over a year (1 year 3 months). You would think with all of this technology, it would be built in 6 months. Can't do that though. The job has to go on as long as possible. So people don't notice, they'll throw in delays and excuses as well.

I would love for a piece of the old tower to be made into a statue memoralizing that day. I know they kept some scrape for that purpose. I think a section, 2-3 stories high in the lobby would be fitting.

I've heard a lot of reasons/excuses for the delays ... but that's the first time I've heard that one. From a civil engineering standpoint it takes a year almost to get the foundations in... also, the old foundation would have to be demo'd or rendered inert. Both of which takes a long time. Finally... it appears that funding has become an issue. do you think that Obama or Congress should allocate funding for the project in light of everything else? Or would that be just one more barb that people can stick him with?

title: A new name for the building at Ground Zero

content: quote: From a civil engineering standpoint it takes a year almost to get the foundations in... also, the old foundation would have to be demo'd or rendered inert. Both of which takes a long time. Also incorporating rail and light rail(?) into the design and linking it in physically is not that easy Finally... it appears that funding has become an issue. do you think that Obama or Congress should allocate funding for the project in light of everything else? Those are all reasons I've heard before ... as well as the bickering among survivors/family members/first responders and the planners on the whole site design, piece parts of the site design, and the memorial design ... and the fact that the entire "Freedom Tower" building design was changed after the cornerstone was laid. I made my position on federal funding pretty clear earlier in the thread ... with no partisanship involved.
quote: From a civil engineering standpoint it takes a year almost to get the foundations in... also, the old foundation would have to be demo'd or rendered inert. Both of which takes a long time. I made my position on federal funding pretty clear earlier in the thread ... with no partisanship involved.

title: A new name for the building at Ground Zero

content: Personally, I'm less concerned about the name than I am about the fact the site hasn't been rebuilt yet. The best response, IMO, would have been to rebuild BOTH towers, even taller, in the shortest time possible.
reply: Personally, I'm less concerned about the name than I am about the fact the site hasn't been rebuilt yet. The best response, IMO, would have been to rebuild BOTH towers, even taller, in the shortest time possible.
title: A new name for the building at Ground Zero

content: And ... the developer is looking for a government handout ... quote: New York, Mar 22 (PTI) The private developer responsible for rebuilding the World Trade Center site has asked the United States government for providing "crucial financial assistance," a media report says. Citing people familiar with the matter, the Wall Street Journal said: "The rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, already hobbled by years of delays and infighting, is facing fresh problems as private developer Larry Silverstein asks the government for crucial financial assistance." The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the government entity that owns the site, is eager to prevent the project from stalling, and is considering helping to finance at least one of Silverstein's planned three office towers, WSJ added quoting sources. Silverstein is requesting financing help on at least two of the three towers. The project, meant to be a symbol of the recovery after the September 11 terrorist attacks, has been through years of costly delays and acrimony. The plan for the 16-acre site includes five skyscrapers, a memorial, a transit hub, a shopping mall and a performing-arts center. Much of that was recently expected to open between 2011 and 2013. PTI "http://www.ptinews.com/pti%5Cptisite.nsf/0/6630599EF9FCA69A65257581003F74B7?OpenDocument" Not just NO ... but HELL NO.

Instead we might as well call it: The tower we built so Americans will have a place to go to surrender and beg for the mercy of the divine worldy better then us , which is everyone, and we're so sorry ofr being american and creating a system that allowed us to do better then well..everyone, so please take our women just let us live in peace tower. I’m sorry you feel like this about yourself! I was channeling a liberal..as for me: I am an American Soldier. I am a Warrior and a member of a team. I serve the people of the United States, and live the Army Values. I will always place the mission first. I will never accept defeat. I will never quit. I will never leave a fallen comrade. I am disciplined, physically and mentally tough, trained and proficient in my warrior tasks and drills. I always maintain my arms, my equipment and myself. I am an expert and I am a professional. I stand ready to deploy, engage, and destroy, the enemies of the United States of America in close combat. I am a guardian of freedom and the American way of life. I am an American Soldier.

title: A new name for the building at Ground Zero

content: Just to give a comparison. The Empire state building was built in a little over a year (1 year 3 months). You would think with all of this technology, it would be built in 6 months. Can't do that though. The job has to go on as long as possible. So people don't notice, they'll throw in delays and excuses as well.
reply: Just to give a comparison. The Empire state building was built in a little over a year (1 year 3 months). You would think with all of this technology, it would be built in 6 months. Can't do that though. The job has to go on as long as possible. So people don't notice, they'll throw in delays and excuses as well.

content: quote: Originally posted by Raunchy: quote: Originally posted by Knele: Freedom Tower is right up there with Freedom Fries...... What an idiotic comparison. The word Freedom Tower was a knee jerk reaction... yes it was needed... but it still was a kneejerk reaction... just like the word Freedom Fries. That said... I would love for a piece of the old tower to be made into a statue memoralizing that day. I know they kept some scrape for that purpose. I think a section, 2-3 stories high in the lobby would be fitting.

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: Originally posted by john2x: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Instead of a monument of sorts, it is becoming a monumental embarassment. At the rate it is going, by the time construction is completed there won't be anyone left alive that lived through that fateful day. Takes time to cart off all the contaminated soil and replace it which has been going on for years now at night in prep for the construction. LOL ... I've heard a lot of reasons/excuses for the delays ... but that's the first time I've heard that one. From a civil engineering standpoint it takes a year almost to get the foundations in... also, the old foundation would have to be demo'd or rendered inert. Both of which takes a long time. Finally... it appears that funding has become an issue. do you think that Obama or Congress should allocate funding for the project in light of everything else? Or would that be just one more barb that people can stick him with?

content: quote: From a civil engineering standpoint it takes a year almost to get the foundations in... also, the old foundation would have to be demo'd or rendered inert. Both of which takes a long time. Also incorporating rail and light rail(?) into the design and linking it in physically is not that easy Finally... it appears that funding has become an issue. do you think that Obama or Congress should allocate funding for the project in light of everything else? Those are all reasons I've heard before ... as well as the bickering among survivors/family members/first responders and the planners on the whole site design, piece parts of the site design, and the memorial design ... and the fact that the entire "Freedom Tower" building design was changed after the cornerstone was laid. I made my position on federal funding pretty clear earlier in the thread ... with no partisanship involved.
